repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - First Programmatic Human
            Development Reform Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The findings indicate that the original goals
            of the reform continue to be valid and second and third
            phases of the Human Development Reform Loan (HDRP) are
            clearly warranted to achieve them. Although it did not fully
            prepare the second phase of the program as anticipated, the
            first phase provided valuable lessons and insights that
            should be accounted for in the second and third phases. As
            originally designed, Social Security Administration (IESS)
            was expected to be a major instrument in reaching program
            goals. It was directly involved in completing 6 monitorable
            actions, including two triggers for a second stage. Reforms
            are underway to restore economic and financial stability in
            Ecuador. Technical Secretariat of the Interministerial
            Social Sectors Committee (STFS) has established a sound
            record in monitoring and motivating the program to date, and
            should continue this role in the future. It is clear that
            steps taken to coordinate existing agencies has not led to
            desired breadth of reform proposals needed to successfully
            address pension reforms and reform of nutritional and food
            security programs.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Programmatic Human Development
            Reform Loan Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
There is clear evidence that indigenous
            populations have been systematically disadvantaged, namely,
            that by living in poor rural areas, indigenous groups have
            faced limited access to education and health, compared to
            other groups in Ecuador. Interventions for the specific
            benefit of indigenous groups will be incorporated into the
            project design, and, this Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP)
            summarizes specific actions to these efforts. The main
            elements in this plan will focus on: increased level of
            participation of indigenous peoples, and representatives in
            the design of program actions (empowerment); improved rural
            focus of actions (geographic equity); and, tightened
            targeting of measures intended for the poor, so as to
            effectively shift program coverage in their favor
            (interpersonal equity). Regarding education, an improved
            intercultural and bilingual education will be offered,
            enhancing the technical performance of teachers in their
            deliverance of intercultural and bilingual education, with
            specific linkages to other social services to raise
            children's readiness to receive such education. Teacher
            availability will be addressed in the program. Regarding
            health issues, the program will address coverage of the
            uninsured - mostly poor, and indigenous mothers and children
            - through the Rural Social Security services, supported by
            physical and human resources. The program will also address
            social security issues, focused on making a redistribution
            of available social security resources, through improvements
            at the Administration's level, while as a complement to
            the regulatory and administrative reforms in social
            services, an "open access" to information policy
            and support to operational infrastructure, will be developed.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Programmatic Human Development
            Reform Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government of Ecuador, which took
            office January 15, 2003, is undertaking a new program to
            establish macroeconomic stability and the conditions for the
            resumption of growth and the reduction of poverty, following
            one of the worst economic crisis in recent history. Both the
            World Bank and IMF are providing financial assistance to
            this effort. Concurrently, the Government has committed
            itself to protect and enhance social sector spending and
            program efficiency in the immediate term, and initiate
            reforms in key social sectors -health, social protection,
            and education- to provide a regulatory and institutional
            platform for medium and longer-term structural improvements
            in those areas. This project would be the first phase of the
            Bank's support to achieving these goals. The HDRL, like
            the overall program would focus on three critical aspects of
            social service reforms: (i) protecting and enhancing
            Ecuador's public sector investment in social sectors by
            supporting rationalized institutional budgets and financing
            for key social programs; (ii) increasing the efficiency and
            effectiveness of social programs through refocusing program
            objectives, improving targeting of social services, raising
            consistency in their administration, and promoting resource
            sharing among institutions; and (iii) enhancing the public
            consultations, transparency and accountability in the
            implementation of social programs.
